items.title: [Python] [sklearn] Text features as input to sklearn interface
items.body:
Hi all,

Is there an example on how to use **text features in the VW sklearn API**? I can not make the `sklearn_vw.tovw()` function work. I'm interested in this function because tovw is used by sklearn_vw.VW to convert the regular input into VW-compatible format. There seems to be 2 separate problems, both related to `sklearn.datasets.svmlight_format.dump_svmlight_file()` usage by `tovw`. The first is a small feature, which can be worked around by additional type casting, but the second is unclear to me.

1). There is a mis-handling of pandas.Series objects as an input, which seems to be due to the dtype being `'object'`. Below is a dummy example to reproduce the problem:
```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from vowpalwabbit.sklearn_vw import tovw

X = pd.Series(['cat', 'dog', 'cat', 'cat'], name='catdog')
y = pd.Series([-1, 1, -1, -1], name='label')

tovw(X, y)
```
The output is 
```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-705a017a4383> in <module>()
      8 y = pd.Series([-1, 1, -1, -1], name='label')
      9 
---> 10 tovw(X, y)

.../vowpalwabbit/sklearn_vw.py in tovw(x, y, sample_weight)
    579     # convert input to svmlight format
    580     s = io.BytesIO()
--> 581     dump_svmlight_file(x, np.zeros(rows), s)
    582 
    583     # parse entries to construct VW format

.../sklearn/datasets/svmlight_format.py in dump_svmlight_file(X, y, f, zero_based, comment, query_id, multilabel)
    445                              % (yval.shape,))
    446 
--> 447     Xval = check_array(X, accept_sparse='csr')
    448     if Xval.shape[0] != yval.shape[0]:
    449         raise ValueError("X.shape[0] and y.shape[0] should be the same, got"

.../sklearn/utils/validation.py in check_array(array, accept_sparse, dtype, order, copy, force_all_finite, ensure_2d, allow_nd, ensure_min_samples, ensure_min_features, warn_on_dtype, estimator)
    431                                       force_all_finite)
    432     else:
--> 433         array = np.array(array, dtype=dtype, order=order, copy=copy)
    434 
    435         if ensure_2d:

ValueError: could not convert string to float: 'cat'
```
This can be resolved by passing a `np.array` or strings, i.e. calling `tovw(X.values.astype(str), y)`. This is not elegant and multiple users will bump into the same problem, but it is resolvable. However, this brings us to the second problem.

2). Giving an array of string as X input still leads to another issue with `sklearn.datasets.svmlight_format.dump_svmlight_file()`:

```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-11-42a921e37bc9> in <module>()
      2 y_a = np.array([-1, 1, -1, -1])
      3 
----> 4 tovw(X_a, y_a)

.../vowpalwabbit/sklearn_vw.py in tovw(x, y, sample_weight)
    579     # convert input to svmlight format
    580     s = io.BytesIO()
--> 581     dump_svmlight_file(x, np.zeros(rows), s)
    582 
    583     # parse entries to construct VW format

.../sklearn/datasets/svmlight_format.py in dump_svmlight_file(X, y, f, zero_based, comment, query_id, multilabel)
    476 
    477     if hasattr(f, "write"):
--> 478         _dump_svmlight(X, y, f, multilabel, one_based, comment, query_id)
    479     else:
    480         with open(f, "wb") as f:
.../sklearn/datasets/svmlight_format.py in _dump_svmlight(X, y, f, multilabel, one_based, comment, query_id)
    352             row = zip(np.where(nz)[0], X[i, nz])
    353 
--> 354         s = " ".join(value_pattern % (j + one_based, x) for j, x in row)
    355 
    356         if multilabel:
.../sklearn/datasets/svmlight_format.py in <genexpr>(.0)
    352             row = zip(np.where(nz)[0], X[i, nz])
    353 
--> 354         s = " ".join(value_pattern % (j + one_based, x) for j, x in row)
    355 
    356         if multilabel:

TypeError: only size-1 arrays can be converted to Python scalars
```

**Environmental setup**
Ubuntu 16.04 with conda 4.5.1 and python3.5 
vowpalwabbit  8.5.0 (installed from pypi), scikit-learn 0.19.1, numpy  1.14.2

Any feedback/help would be appreciated.

Cheers,
Misha

items.title: [Python] [sklearn] A few issues (and minor bugs?) in the sklearn_vw.VW.fit() method
items.body:
Hi,

playing around with the sklearn interface of VW it seems there a few issues (applies to v 8.5.0 and the current master branch):
1. A **very minor bug**: it seems that the code intends to shuffle examples between epochs/passes. This is done [here in the code](https://github.com/JohnLangford/vowpal_wabbit/blob/master/python/vowpalwabbit/sklearn_vw.py#L307). However, `range(n)` starts with `0`, so the `n > 1` condition has to be changed to `n >= 1` otherwise the second pass is done without reshuffling.
2. An **issue/bug** (?): the current implementation of shuffling doesn't work in a general case for pd.DataFrame or pd.Series as an input. It will work if all indices are sequential starting from 0. However, if one attempts to use a KFold splitting from sklearn, then it breaks down. A minimal example to reproduce the problem is given at the end of the post. This feature can be worked around by passing `pd.Series.values` but at the moment it is not clear from the documentation that pandas objects directly have only a limited support. Pandas support also relates to observations in #1472.
3. An **issue**: even if a `np.array` is passed directly, the `VW.fit()` with several passes shuffles examples in the original array. The problem with this is that one wants to evaluate performance on tthe training dataset, thus doing `clf.predict()` and to compare to a vector (=array/pd.Series/etc.) true labels. True labels are usually available separately in a sklearn nomenclature (i.e. 0/1 labels instead of -1/1). However, those have not been shuffled and thus the order of predictions and true labels is broken and performance metric evaluation doesn't make sense. Is it possible to create a local copy of the input data object inside the `.fit()` method and clear it at the end? Otherwise, the documentation has to be very explicit about this behaviour.

Thanks in advance for feedback

**Environmental setup**
Ubuntu 16.04 with conda 4.5.1 and python3.5
vowpalwabbit 8.5.0 (installed from pypi), scikit-learn 0.19.1, numpy 1.14.2

**Example of the issue 2**
```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from vowpalwabbit.sklearn_vw import VWClassifier
from sklearn.model_selection import KFold

# The dummy example X has already been adjusted to the native VW format, so convert_to_vw=False
X = pd.Series(['1 |Pet cat', '-1 |Pet dog', '1 |Pet cat', '1 |Pet cat'], name='catdog')
# The sklearn-friendly y is needed for the KFold.split() only
y = pd.Series([-1, 1, -1, -1], name='label')

kfold = KFold(n_splits=3, random_state=314, shuffle=False)

# Split the data in folds for cross validation
for train_idx, valid_idx in kfold.split(X, y):
    train_cv, valid_cv = X[train_idx], X[valid_idx]
    # Classifier with a single pass over the data 
    clf = VWClassifier(passes=1, convert_to_vw=False)
    # This will work
    clf.fit(train_cv)
    print('done with a single pass')

    # Classifier with a 3 passes over the data  (i.e. reshuffling should take place)
    clf = VWClassifier(passes=3, convert_to_vw=False)
    # This will still work
    clf.fit(train_cv.values)
    print('done with 3 passes on np.array')
    # This will NOT work
    print('Current indices: ' + str(train_cv.index.values))
    clf.fit(train_cv)
    print('done with 3 passes on pd.Series')
```
The output is:
```python 
done with a single pass
done with 3 passes on np.array
Current indices: [2 3]

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-12-43a4b42f3a13> in <module>()
     26     # This will NOT work
     27     print('Current indices: ' + str(train_cv.index.values))
---> 28     clf.fit(train_cv)
     29     print('done with 3 passes on pd.Series')

~/anaconda2/envs/Titanic/lib/python3.5/site-packages/vowpalwabbit/sklearn_vw.py in fit(self, X, y, sample_weight)
    306         for n in range(self.passes_):
    307             if n > 1:
--> 308                 np.random.shuffle(X)
    309             for idx, x in enumerate(X):
    310                 model.learn(x)

mtrand.pyx in mtrand.RandomState.shuffle()

--> 623             result = self.index.get_value(self, key)
```

items.title: [Python] [sklearn] Documentation of the API and a few questions
items.body:
Hi,

I'm just starting to use VW in python. I'm very happy that there is a python binding and one dores not need to go around to dump `.vw` files with custom functions, running from a command line and then reading in the predictions in python again. And in particular, the sklearn wrapper is very useful, as it allows to use multiple handy functionalities from that package and makes usage universal across many algorithms. So thanks a lot!

I have a few questions to this interface:
1. Is there a documentation of the API (pyvw in general, and sklearn_vw in particular)? Would it be possible to add auto-generated docs from the class and function description? For example, one can use [Sphinx](http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/) for that or any other tool that you would fancy. This will help users to find information faster.
2. I wanted to understand how exactly training is handled by the sklearn interface. It seems that there are 2 regimes: 
2.1 VW native approach based on a `.vw` file. This seems to be enabled by the `data` arg in the constructor and learning done in the `pyvw.vw()` instantiation in `get_vw()`. Is that understanding correct? If so, this is very nice as it allows online training with a restricted memory footprint, as advertised by the tool. However, from [here](https://github.com/JohnLangford/vowpal_wabbit/blob/master/python/vowpalwabbit/sklearn_vw.py#L251), it seems that even in this case one runs one (and always only one) _additional_ pass over the data provided to the `.fit()` function. Would it make sense to set the number of passes to 0 in this case?
2.2 The sklearn-like interface based on in-memory X and y arrays. In this case one iterates over `pyvw.vw.learn()` calls. That's fine for small datasets, I imagine. It also makes start of VW usage for people with sklearn experience much faster and smoother. The only thing here, would it be possible to add an additional parameter to the constructor that would be specific to the sklearn API and would allow one to convert `[0,1]` labels in the classification into `[-1,1]`. This simplifies life a lot, since in most cases data have `0` label instead of `-1`. One can maybe even reuse the existing `convert_to_vw_` attribute to trigger this conversion, but this would not be backward-compatible (I'm not sure how many people use the sklearn interface of VW by now).

Related to the approach discussed in 2.1, why is `fit_` attritube set to `True` already in the constructor in this case? It seems that the actual fit is done still inside `get_vw()` call from `.fit()`. I might have got it wrong, but if I'm right, than this defies the definition of the `fit_` attribute, as it leads to actual model fit inside `.predict()` call, which would make this call slow and confuse a user, is `.fit()` was never called.

I'm happy to help with implementation of some of the issues discussed above, if you find them useful.

Cheers,
Misha

items.title: Add grouping to Python sklearn interface
items.body:
Adds support to pass through `groups` & `group_sizes` to XGBoost's `sklearn` interface.

~~This is more of a proof of concept, I want to rework the interface so that `groups` is used the way the `sklearn` does things.  With `sklearn` groups should be a group identifier, while for `xgboost` it expects the data to be sorted by group, and then given group sizes.  I was thinking about making a `group_sizes` parameter, and then having a `groups` parameter that works the `sklearn` way.  Let me know if that sounds good!~~

This adds ability to build ranking models through the `sklearn` API, by setting `.fit(X, y, groups=groups)`, which will now:
1) resort the data so groups are next to each other (based on `groups`)
2) on the created dmatrix, it will call `DMatrix.set_group(...)` with the calculated group sizes
3) goes through existing `Booster.predict(...)` code path
4) resorts the results back to what they original were
5) returns back to what called the `sklearn` API

I also passed through `group_sizes` if the programmer would rather use the XGBoost style of handing grouping, instead of how sklearn handles it (which is to assign a group number for every row).

#815 seems related, but it looks like they just jumped down to using `DMatrix` & `train` directly... but I have a bunch of parameter tuning setup so I don't want to rework that code. 😄
